reviewText: One Man's Hero directed by Lance Hool is a good film to watch if you want to understand the most neglected aspect of America's history, namely our war of expansionism with Mexico.  This film will give you an understanding of the animosity between Americans and Mexicans.  Tom Berenger plays real life character John Riley.  The American army in those days was rife with anti-Catholicism, much like the surrounding culture of the day.  Catholics in the US Army, mostly Irish, but some Germans and others deserted because of harsh treatment.  The film does a good job of giving you the viewpoints of many important people in this part of our combined American and Mexican history, namely Zachary Taylor, future President and vocal opponent of the war, General Winfield Scott, who hoping the war will catapult him to the Presidency bleeds his field units dry, while embracing a lot of symbolism over substance.  And, the Mexicans, who will oppossed to the American presence in their land, have no use for the Mexican military leadership, lacking in any real tactical skill, nor its government run by the dictator General Santa Ana.  This movie will get you up to snuff on the infamous San Patricio Brigade, American Immigrants, who deserted the US Army and fought for Mexico, and the Mexican War.  As I remember being taught American history, it went something like, the colonies, the American Revolution, let's not forget the War of 1812, the Louisiana Purchase, the Alamo, and jump right to the American Civil War.  This film will explain that shame, and fill in the blanks.  A great action yarn that stays true to history.
summary: AN IMPORTAN BUT NEGLECTED PART OF OUR HISTORY
Title: N/A

reviewText: One Man's Hero, 2000 filmThe film begins with old photos and drawings from the early 19th century. This story takes place in the 1840s. We see some army prisoners being lashed as punishment. Catholics who wanted to go to church for their obligations. This is looked upon with disfavor by their Protestant officers, who denied them permission and then ordered them flogged while tied to a cartwheel. This is stopped by a soldier with a pistol who frees these soldiers. Later when the fleeing soldiers stop to rest they are attacked by Mexicans. The US Colonel returns, too late to fix the problem. [It was not unusual for sergeants to be promoted to officers then.] These fleeing soldiers can't go either north (deserters) or south (the enemy). A Mexican general offers them a choice: join the Mexican army or die. They join the San Patricio Brigade. They defend Monterey against attack under their green flag. There is a cannonade against the attacking US troops.The American troops are victorious, the Mexicans retreat to the Citadel fortress. The Mexicans surrender and leave the city. One American soldier tries to grab their green flag. The Mexican forces are defeated again. Mexican gunpowder is inferior unlike the corned gunpowder of America (more graft and corruption?). What will the San Patricio Brigade do? The American infantry charge, the cannons fire. The infantry attack continues until the Mexicans retreat. The San Patricio Brigade is captured. Many of them were British subjects. [Will the British do anything?] General Winfield Scott will punish them for the morale of the army. The hangings occur after the battle of Chapultepec.This is based on a true story. In the Civil War the term "Galvanized Yankee" was used for Yankees who joined the Confederate army, and then for Confederates who joined the Union army. There has never been any other examples of American soldiers who joined the enemy. Europe has a long history of troops who turned their coats to join the other side. Ethnic and cultural affinities are still important. This film does not mention any other events that caused dissension. The details of the Mexican War is under played in school textbooks, as if to hide the opposition to this war in America. This mistreatment would never have happened in the militia units where the officers were elected by enlisted soldiers. Until the 20th century most soldiers came from militia units (also censored from history books).After the successful Mexican Revolution around 1820 the Monroe Doctrine (not a law) provided a shield against a re-conquest by European powers. American politicians helped to write the 1824 Mexican Constitution that was modeled on the US Constitution. Mexico sought settlers form America and Europe to fill the empty lands where the Indians lived. But the big landowners and bankers did not want liberty and equality for the people. They sought a dictator who staged a coup to overthrow this democratic government and create a centralized government run by the aristocracy. Revolts broke out in most Mexican states, but Santa Anna put down these revolts. Texas alone was able reject the Santa Anna dictatorship and become an independent republic in 1836. Zacatecas, after being defeated, suffered the slaughter of the supporters of the 1824 Constitution and looting . A powerful military became the ruler not the ruled, people suffered from high taxes and low wages to benefit the aristocracy. A good history book will educate you about these events. This film provides drama, not history.
summary: A Story about the San Patricio Brigade

reviewText: So there I am, sitting on my couch blissfully unaware of the fact that I am about to be awash in a 160 year old Irish/American/Mexican controversy, when suddenly and without warning, "One Man's Hero" should pop up on....  Several websites later, and after reading the customer reviews here, I find it interesting that a page in our history that has been virtually ignored for 160 years can still bring about such heated feelings of patriotism and racism. ....  For the less sensitive and more open-minded however, this film while not that great, should at least be credited for it's willingness to shed light on both an obscure and shameful part of U.S. history.  I will agree with the above mentioned patriot that at times there does seem to be an over willingness in the media to trash Uncle Sam and the American way of life. But, this is a true story and truth and justice are the American way. Aren't they? People that turn their backs on history, scare me. So let's learn from our mistakes, and let's all get along. Okay? By the way, there are several books out there about the "San Patricios" both historical and fictional, if your interested.

reviewText: This film addressed a shameful part of America's military past.  It told of the brutal mistreatment of Irish (and other) immigrants enlisted in the Saint Patrick's Batallion shortly before and during the Mexican War.  Anti-Catholic persecuted these soldiers, punishing them for attending Sunday mass and treating them terribly in general.  Many left and fled to Mexico, eventually fighting for Mexico.  They paid a high price.The film, on further checking, proved to be quite accurate historically.  Especially brutal executions really happened as were the war sequences.
summary: A brutal story of an American travesty

reviewText: THE STORY HAS BEEN "ENHANCED" BUT IS ESSENTIALLY TRUE.MY FAMILY HAS BEEN IN AMERICA SINCE THE 1850'S AND I AM AMERICAN ... WITH IRISH "ROOTS" .... AND CHEROKEE, AND AFRICAN, AND ENGLISH (UGH) AND ???I LOVE MY COUNTRY AND ITS PEOPLE ... HOWEVER NOT ALL OF US HAVE ALWAYS ACTED AS WE OUGHT TO HAVE DONE.  AS WITH THE AFRICAN PEOPLE, THE IRISH WERE BADLY TREATED BY SOME OF OUR COUNTRYMEN ... ESPECIALLY WERE THE IRISH CATHOLICS SORELY BESET UPON BY THE ANGLO-WASPS.I CAN STILL HEAR MY GRANDMOTHER MAKING REFERENCE TO "THOSE BLOODY SASSENACH BASTARDS".  SHE WAS A FIRST GENERATION AMERICAN BORN IRISH-CATHOLIC WOMAN AND WAS NO DOUBT CASTING HER SLUR UPON THE ENGLISH PROTESTANTS WHO HAD CAUSED HER FAMILY SO MUCH GRIEF IN IRELAND ... AND SHE WAS NO DOUBT ONLY REPEATING WHAT SHE HAD HEARD ... AS AM I.SO, WHEN I COME TO WATCH THIS FILM, I COME WITH MY OWN BAGGAGE ... THROUGH WHICH I VERY MUCH RELATE WITH THESE "SAN PATRICIOS".  I AM NOT A FILM-MAKER, NOR DO I HAVE KNOWLEDGE IN THAT CRAFT FROM WHICH TO LAUNCH A "CRITIQUE" OF IT QUA "FILM".  BUT I ENJOYED IT AND BELIEVE THAT A CERTAIN ASPECT OF THE IRISH EXPERIENCE IN AMERICA HAS BEEN WELL PORTRAYED.THESE "SAN PATRICIOS" HAD THEIR MARCHING SONG WITH THE TITLE AND LYRICS OF "GREEN GROWS THE GRASS OF HOME". IT NO LONGER IS THAT BUT HAS BECOME A SLUR ON THE MEXICAN TONGUE TOWARDS ALL THINGS "ANGLO".WHERE DOES THIS "VENDETTA" END UNLESS WE WRAP OURSELVES IN CHRIST AND LEARN FROM HIM TO BE TOLERANT, CHARITABLE AND FORGIVING.  AMEN.

reviewText: This movie is set in the southwest US and Mexico during the 1840s and tells the story of how Irish, German and other immigrants in the US Army deserted and instead joined Mexico's army to fight against the US invasion of Mexico.  There were more than 1,000 Irish immigrants who formed the San Patricio (St. Patrick) Battalion in the Mexican Army, and like most Mexicans of the time, they were Catholic and so shared a common religious bond.  They also apparently did not like what they saw while in service of the US Army, which at that time was marching deep into Mexico and capturing city after city.  The movie tells the story of the San Patricios' valiant actions and bravery in various battles, but also tells of their ultimate defeat.  Tom Berenger plays the real-life leader of the San Patricios who left his long career as a US Army sergeant to become a commanding officer in the Mexican army and lead his fellow Irishmen.  The invasion resulted in Mexico's defeat and, in order to achieve peace, it was forced to give up 40% of its country to the US, land that is now California, Nevada, Colorado, Arizona, Utah and New Mexico.  An excellent movie based on real people that tells the story of a historical period that is little known here in the US.
summary: Excellent movie about little-known period in US history

reviewText: While Tom Berenger's brogue leaves much to be desired, this is a fascinating slice of history....Nearly 1600 years ago, Saint Patrick arrived in Ireland, to meet a "people who still practiced human sacrifice, who warred with each other constantly and who were renowned as the great slave traders of the day" (Anita McSorley, The Saint Patrick You Never Knew, St. Anthony Messenger, March 1997).  With his introduction of Christianity and its respect for human life, Patrick facilitated a dramatic decline in war and murder, as well as an end to the slave trade.  In subsequent centuries, Saint Patrick's respect for human life has continued to inspire Irish heroism."One Man's Hero" relates an incident which seems largely ingnored in American history books.  During the Mexican-American War, a group of Catholic immigrants - most of whom were Irish - actually switched sides.  To a very large extent, they appear to have been responding to inhumane treatment of Mexican people[...]in the American military.
summary: San Patricios in Defense of Human Life

reviewText: I had never heard of this 1998 film but the theme intrigued me.  It's based on the true story of a group of Irish young men who came to United States during the potato famine and were promised immediate citizenship if they enlisted in the U.S. Army which was then waging a war with Mexico.Tom Berenger is cast in the lead role as a sergeant who disobeys his American Protestant peers by daring to go to a Catholic Mass with a dozen of his men.  This offense is punishable by a brutal lashing, after which the group goes AWOL over the Mexican border where they are first attacked by and then convinced to fight on the Mexican side.This is a great theme and, if only there were better acting, directing and casting, I might have liked it. All the actors seemed to be reading their lines with little emotion.  The romantic interest between Tom Berenger and a Mexican woman had no spark at all.  The screenplay oozes with dialog that is so preachy and insipid that I almost laughed out loud.  And, to top it all off, it was boring.I watched a little more than a half hour before shutting it off.  And then I thought about how that half hour was a total waste of time.Don't waste your time on it either.
summary: Good theme - but horrible acting, directing and casting

reviewText: One Man's Hero is a beautiful film. Beneath any flaws in style and editing, discussions of touchy subject matter, etc. etc., it presents the incredible true story of a group of Irish immigrants who deserted the US army to fight with Mexico during the Mexican War to become the San Patricios. For an $ million film and fairly unknown director, it stands the test well and emerges an educational and compelling  piece of moviemaking.Truth be told, there's nothing spectacular about the battle scenes or any groundbreaking aspects, but the collective strength of the cast and the solid script pay homage to these men. The film boasts several brilliant "moments", a sub-plot romance, wonderful performances from supporting cast, a thought provoking subject from the archives of history, and the drama and charismatic profundity of a lost cause and ultimate tragedy. Kudos to great score and utilizing the terrain to the benefit of the film.Though it's not a blazing Oscar candidate, this is a wonderful, sad, and highly personal film about human beings trying to make the best of an unusual and dangerous situation. It has a layered cultural atmosphere that is refreshing and enlightening, and no doubt you'll end the film with a new appreciation of history and belief in film.
summary: Captivating film about a tragic story
Title: N/A

reviewText: "One Man's Hero" is the true story of a group of Irish-Catholic soldiers who desert the US Army at the outbreak of the Mexican-American War.  Berenger plays their hard-nosed sergeant who rescues them from a brutal whipping for attending a Catholic church service without permission. Once they run away and learn that war has been declared they decide to fight alongside the Mexicans (who are overwhelmingly Catholic), rather than go back to the US Army and face more whipping. This band of Erin's soldiers is called the St Patrick's Battalion, and are considered heroes to the Mexicans for standing up for their religious faith.  Great story, great acting by Berenger, and great large-budget effects are hampered by insipid script which goes nowhere beyond cliches. If the script was better I would have given it 4 stars.  Still, its a great movie for history buffs and fans of Berenger.  Well done.

reviewText: I found this movie rather maudlin and over done. Many of the historical "facts" are "fiction" as many other reviewers have already stated.It is true that in the America of the 1840s (and before and after) there was wide spread anti-Catholicism. But Mr. Riley could go to any city in the United States and find an RC church and worship as he pleased. How many Protestant churches I wonder did he see in Mexico? Did he know that American emigrants to Texas were required by Mexican law to convert? Some of my ancestors were Huguenots. Irish Catholic "martyrs" should read what the "tolerant" French Catholics did after the revocation of the Edict of Nantes before they go blathering about their own experience.

reviewText: ...is another man's traitor. That's the way it is: the San Patricios are heroes -rightly so- to us Mexicans and traitors -rightly so as well- to the Americans, for they fought for us and deserted them. To argue about whether  they did the right thing or not is futile; it depends on which side you are  on. History always has two stories to tell and that's what makes it  fascinating.However, I'm not so sure I liked this movie even if most of  what it shows is true. I commend the fact that being this, to my knowledge,  the only American movie ever made about the Mexican War, it does not repeat  the same old clichés one finds in all those Alamo movies, where the  Mexicans are but  laughing hyenas and the Americans angels on the side of  justice. Of course, it could hardly be portrayed that way in this case,  given the unjust nature of this particular war. But I think the movie goes  the other way a little too much: the Mexicans are idealized beyond  recognition, and that doesn't help history either.The truth is the  United States invaded Mexico when  that country was having a civil war of  its own. That's why we were weaker, that's why we lost, and that should  have been made explicit in the movie. Instead it goes for the 'suffering  defenseless noble peasant' stereotype Hollywood always uses whenever it  wants to show Mexicans in a better light. I've seen it in 'Viva Zapata!',  I've seen it in 'The Magnificent Seven', in 'The Wild Bunch', in countless  other pictures and, frankly, I'm as fed up with it as with the greaser one.  Please portray us as normal people for once!All that romantically  patriotic menáge à trois between Tom Berenger, Daniela Romo and Joaquim De  Almeida merely sinks the movie. Whoever thought those awful lines, let  alone those characters? Mexicans don't talk that way! Don't do us no  favors, it only makes us sound like tragic proud imbeciles! And as for  historical accuracy, John O'Reilly did not "dissappeared into the  mountains of Mexico" as the movie so cornly concludes, but ended his  days a blind beggar in the streets of Mexico City, a fact that shames me as  a Mexican. I think the San Patricios deserved better, both in real life and  in the movie.

reviewText: Late 2003 addendum: Below is my original review posted in late 2000; it basically stands, but after a few further reviewings, I'm now inclined to be less harsh in my initial assessment (add a half star to the above rating).  For one thing, I've decided that watching this in the widescreen format (the DVD offers both widescreen and standard format options) improves the overall experience enormously.  The cinematography and production design are actually pretty solid, but this is not apparent in the compressed image.  Opening up the screen really opens up the action and the composition is revealed to be much more careful and expressive than a cursory viewing  reveals.  The Mexican locations and sets are used to good effect.  Important details that explain some of the battlefield actions are no longer lost off the edge of the screen.I'm also feeling more kindly toward the bravery of the filmmakers daring to make a film portaying the USA as an aggressor and hypocrite.  No wonder this film saw only limited theatrical release (if any) -- in this post-9-11 environment, I doubt a movie of this type could be made at all by an American studio.  We no longer wish our safe assumptions about our moral superiority questioned, or our honorable intentions impugned, despite a historical record that is often very shabby, as accurately depicted in "One Man's Hero."  For many people, the truth hurts; yet, facing the truth is the only thing that allows us to grow as individuals and as a society.  The day we cease our quest for understanding the truth about persons or nations, is the day that freedom dies.  Perhaps this film beats the drum a bit too shrilly on behalf of the Irish, the Mexicans, the Catholics, but this  provides useful balance to an industry that normally is only too happy to churn out mindless patriotic cheerleading  and reminds the audience that the rest of the world does not  necessarily turn a blind eye to our misdeeds.  History is not black and white and does not begin or end at the American border.  If we want the world's respect and cooperation today, we should be mindful of the lessons to be learned from our history, especially the less-than-savory episodes.Finally, a  lingering criticism -- these rustic Irishmen are certainly well educated!  There are a few too many quotations from  famous works of literature to be believeable.original review:***There are huge themes to be examined in One Man's Hero; unfortunately, the film only pays cursory attention to these in favor of flat characters and stock war movie conventions.  Where do  a man's true loyalties lie?  With country and flag?  With his religious convictions?  Or simply to those near and dear to him?  If the script spent more time probing these questions and less on treading worn pathways, One Man's Hero might have risen beyond itself. As it is, we are left with an occasionally engaging but ultimately less-than-satisfying action-drama.  A pity, because the Mexican War has almost never received any attention from the cinema, and the true story of the San Patricio Battalion -- Irish Catholic deserters from the US Army who took up arms for Mexico -- would make a tremendous epic in the right hands.There are too many references and borrowings from other historical movies, as if combining enough scenes or characters or snatches of dialogue from Braveheart et al. would fill the time between battle sequences (which are only average and frequently defy military logic -- didn't they employ any military advisors or other historical consultants/reenactors for this shoot?).  The pace is slow, attempts at humor seem forced, and the motivations and historical context often unclear.  The subplot involving the bandido gang is very awkward, intrusive, and unbelieveable and only interferes with the real storyline (imagine if the producers of Gettysburg had felt it necessary to add "romantic interest" in that movie, what a farce it would have been).  Most of the North  Americans are standard-issue villains and most of the Mexicans confused victims -- it's difficult to perceive real events and personalities at work.  Even the two armies, apart from the San Patricios, are seen only as faceless automatons, lacking all definition, existing only to be slaughtered in obligatory slow-mo as their leaders fight one unexplained battle after another. Finally, the scene of Sgt. Riley's branding , for some reason, struck me as just HILARIOUS! in a Monty Python/Richard Lester sort of way, and I'm sure it was supposed to be anything but.  (Is this a sign of poor acting/directing, a script in need of a rewrite, or just my own twisted reaction?)Like I say, a real pity.  The story of the doomed battalion is one of great pathos and sacrifice that cuts across national boundaries.  It still awaits its Shakespeare or Sophocles.
summary: Good intentions, somewhat flawed film, fascinating topic

reviewText: What an odd little movie. Made on a shoestring $11 million budget, "One Man's Hero" was the last film ever released by Orion Pictures and Orion Classics, but it sat on the shelf for a year until MGM -- which had bought Orion -- put it into limited theatrical release in late 1999. The distinguishing feature of this movie is that it tells the story of the Mexican-American War from the perspective of Irish deserters who went over to the Mexican side, forming an artillery unit called the "San Patricios" or St. Patrick's Battalion. That alone makes it memorable, but there are other strong qualities here.Tom Berenger, raised in an Irish Catholic family from Chicago, plays the Irish sergeant John Reilly who leads disaffected Catholic immigrants out of the U.S. Army where they have faced ethnic and religious discrimination. Crossing the border into Mexico, they take up with friendly Mexicans just as the United States declares war on Mexico. Lured to join the Mexican Army rather than return to face the punishment due to deserters, the Irishmen form a foreign legion within the Mexican Army, fighting against their former American countrymen (roughly half of which is Irish like them) in actions deemed treasonable by the U.S. government. Since the Irish had only joined the U.S. Army for citizenship, they didn't feel particularly obligated to the U.S. military, which treated them as second-class citiizens.Fine supporting work in this film comes from James Gammon as sympathetic American General Zachary Taylor, Patrick Bergin as unsympathetic U.S. General Winfield Scott, Stephen Tobolowsky as a bigoted American captain, and the always-charismatic Joachim de Almeida as an unpredictable Mexican rival and friend of  Reilly's. Many of the smaller parts, including a cameo by Prince Albert of Monaco, are also well-cast.Despite some sweeping vistas and occasionally stirring battle scenes, the film is hampered by B-movie cliches and budget filmmaking from producer-turned-director Lance Hool. The plot is an odd mixture of old-fashioned war movie and old-fashioned Western, giving us some great moments (particularly the heroic stands of the Irish in battle and their religious-cultural kinship with the Mexican people) mixed with some hokier scenes.Despite being filmed for theatrical release, the presence of Tom Berenger -- who previously did General Longstreet in "Gettysburg" and Teddy Roosevelt in John Milius' TNT miniseries "Rough Riders") gives the film an instant B-movie or made-for-TV feeling that it labors to shake off. But there is a difference here. Berenger is quite good as the Irish sergeant, giving perhaps his most heartfelt performance, and the fact that we're being asked to root for the Irish AGAINST the United States makes it a memorable turn indeed. He's still Tom Berenger, more of a supporting actor than a star, but he carries the movie pretty well for all that.I first saw this film in college and researched the history behind the events it portrays for a class presentation. I was surprised to discover some Mexican War memoirs of U.S. military officers condemning the San Patricios as filthy traitors, including that of Confederate Admiral Rafael Semmes, which is a particular irony considering that Semmes was later branded as a traitor by that same U.S. military for taking up with the Rebel side in the Civil War. As John Reilly puts it in this film, "one man's traitor is another man's hero." Today the San Patricios are honored as heroes in Mexico and Ireland every year on St. Patrick's Day.This late-1990s DVD is a bare-bones affair, giving only chapter stops and "play" feature in addition to widescreen on one side and fullscreen on the other. Despite some poor nighttime scenes, the picture quality is generally excellent, as is the audio. Although I found "One Man's Hero" an odd and sometimes hokey film when I first saw it, it's turned out to be a movie to which I often return. It is laden with powerful moments and images in addition to a compelling moral conflict about what justifies turning against one's government. Honestly, how many American war movies have you seen that ask you to not merely follow the side fighting the U.S., but ask you to root for that side against the United States? You may be surprised at the emotional impact of finding yourself in that place during "One Man's Hero."
summary: Mexican War from the Irish and Mexican perspective

reviewText: It's amusing to see some "America is never wrong" types get angry. If there was ever a wrong war this was it. It was the US fighting FOR slavery, for more slave territory. And US troops carried out atrocities against Mexicans and Catholic priests. No wonder Irish Catholics deserted.But the gung ho types need not get angry. I wish this film were better. The San Patricios deserve a good film that shows their heroism. This history is not well known and needs a good film.But this isn't it. It's slow, poorly written, with stick figures for characters. It doesn't even show the real history well.

reviewText: "One Man's Hero is another Man's Traitor" quips Sgt. John Reilly in this amazing true story of the St. Patrick's Brigade-- Irish Americans (or were they still British citizen?) who abandoned the U.S. Army in 1846, after cruel and unusual punishment, and fought against the U.S. during the Mexican War.All the leading roles are played by strong actors. Berenger, if 30 pounds too heavy for an authentic portrayal, is always deft in his performances.The role that really caught my eye is that of Cortina, played by the popular Portuguese actor Joaquim de Almeida. He looked so familiar to me but I could only find him listed in one episode of Miami Vice-- surely he deserves some leading parts.The most amazing thing about this film is that the story is true.

reviewText: ...One reviewer in a national magazine gave this film one star.  But then again, he gave "Bride of Chucky" three stars.  Says something about the man......I agree that the love story needlessly bogs down the plot.  Probably the only way that they could get funding for the film.  The story is worthwhile and stands on its own....Reading the true story, one is appalled by the nasty anti-Catholic attitudes and actions of the United States Army.  The government was little better... encouraging Protestant missionaries to go to Mexico to "...convert the Mexicans to Christianity..."...If you watch the film Gettysburg... there is a scene where General Winfield Scott Hancock comes on an Irish regiment at Mass and (though not Catholic himself) removes his hat... being both a true gentleman... and knowing far better than too many of the officers from the Mexican War (where he served and observed...)...The story has unfortunate relevance in that the United States Military is moving from a very neutral but helpful attitude towards religion... to an increasingly direct involvement.  The U.S. Air Force Academy just the tip of the iceberg... From World War I until the early '90s the military had it right......Among other things... if 6% of the troops Jewish... 6% of the chaplains would be Jewish.  But in later years evangelical Christian denominations now have a large and disproportionate representation... While they have some fine chaplains... too many others fail to heed the chaplains creed (Minister to some... chaplain to all) and often show disrespect to the beliefs of service members not of their brand......Worst is the increasing numbers of officers who, in violation of regulations... act as if using their command to push a particular religious movement is perfectly normal... One might have thought that the fiasco in the Mexican American War showed us the folly of such bigotry...
summary: Better than often rated... and relevant...
Title: N/A
